p: In traditional medicine and in clinical practice, T. vulgaris is used, and T. vulgaris shows promising results on inflammatory skin disorders [ 115], scabies, herpes, wounds, alopecia, dental plaque [ 116], ringworm, and headaches [ 106]. Moreover, T. vulgaris showed a promising insecticidal effect on Culex pipiens, the vector for lymphatic filariasis [ 117], demonstrating an increased importance in many fields.
